intro: Sabatia chloroides var. coriacea, commonly known as the roughleaf sand verveine, is a flowering plant native to the eastern United States. It is characterized by its hairy, rough-textured leaves and small, clustered flowers that range in color from white to pink. The plant typically grows in sandy or rocky soils, often in open habitats such as fields and woodland edges. It is a member of the Gentian family (Gentianaceae) and is known for its ability to thrive in nutrient-poor environments. The species is also notable for its ecological role in supporting pollinators such as bees and butterflies.
